Most Illustrious Sir,

The government has received your letter of the 23rd of this month and acknowledges what Your Excellency Captain Félix has reported concerning the enemy's movements.

The government has nothing to add to what it ordered you on the date of yesterday, but expects that you will frequently communicate everything that happens, both regarding your march and that of Colonel Crescêncio, as well as the enemy's movements. Yesterday Lieutenant Manuel Antônio was sent with all the regular troops and the cavalry that could be arranged, to the point that we were left with only a few men for butchering.

If Your Excellency Juca Cipriano, Fialho, etc., remained in the rear guard, the government expects you to promptly inform it so that appropriate measures may be taken.

May God keep Your Excellency.  
Secretariat of War Affairs  
Vacacaí, March 24, 1840  

Most Illustrious Sir Colonel João Antônio da Silveira.  
Serafim Joaquim de Alencastre

Most Illustrious Sir Colonel João Antônio da Silveira, Commander of the Right Division.  
Wherever you may be.  
From the Ministry of War.
